newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-EU TO STUDY ENGLISH PREMIER LEAGUE SATELLITE DEAL.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-EU TO STUDY ENGLISH PREMIER LEAGUE SATELLITE DEAL.

text.p: Europe's competition commissioner Karel van Miert said on Thursday he is to probe a four-year exclusive broadcast rights deal between satellite broadcaster BSkyB and England's Football Association (F.A.).
In an interview broadcast on BBC radio, Van Miert said: "We have to look into the (BSkyB-F.A.) deal and also the duration of the contract."

Asked if he would intervene in the deal he replied, "We certainly will. We certainly will. And what should not happen is that those acquiring the rights will be in such a dominant position that they are going to impose the rules."
BSkyB sealed a 670 million pound ($1.07 billion) contract in June for the rights to transmit live all premier league soccer matches for the next four years.
Last month Van Miert signalled his concern over long-term deals involving ever-larger sums of money in submissions to the European Parliament.
"There is this trend which seriously worries us that increasingly a few large groups can buy such (sports broadcasting) rights," he said.

In August the Commission launched a probe into a plan by the Dutch soccer association KNVB to give a new TV channel called Sport 7, which it partly owns, exclusive rights for seven years over premier and first division matches.
No one was immediately available at BSkyB.
